rsbNotes.title: Isa 56–66
rsbNotes.text: 56:1–66:24 These prophecies are addressed to the exiles returned from Babylon before the rebuilding of the temple in 520 b.c. (64:8–12). They still suffer from idolatry, hypocrisy and indifference. Isaiah prophesies concerning their responsibilities toward the coming glorious kingdom and the certainty of its arrival.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 62:6
rsbNotes.text: 62:6 watchmen. A figure for prophets (56:10 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 62:8
rsbNotes.text:
62:8 has sworn. See note 14:24.

by his right hand and by his mighty arm. That is, by Himself (40:10 note; 41:10; 51:9; 52:10; 53:1).

food for your enemies. The curse (Lev. 26:16; Deut. 28:33) will be replaced by blessing.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 62:10
rsbNotes.text:
62:10 Go through, go through . . . build up, build up. These imperatives emphatically encourage the people to worship.

gates. These lead into the court of the sanctuary (v. 9).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 62:12
rsbNotes.text:
62:12 Holy People. See 4:3; Ex. 19:6; 1 Pet. 2:9, 10.

Redeemed. See note 35:9.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 63:1
rsbNotes.text:
63:1 Edom. This nation is representative of the ungodly and proud nations (34:1–17, especially v. 5; Obad. 14, 15; Lam. 4:21, 22; Joel 3:19; Mal. 1:2–5).

Bozrah. An important city in Edom 30 miles southeast of the Dead Sea.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 63:3
rsbNotes.text: 63:3 winepress . . . stained. This verse presents an extended metaphor for the day of the Lord (Lam. 1:15; Joel 3:13; Rev. 14:17–20; 19:15). The winepress represents the battle, and the juice pressed out represents the casualties of war.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 63:4
rsbNotes.text:
63:4 my year of redemption. This phrase alludes to the laws concerning slaves and property in the Jubilee year (Lev. 25). This idea of redemption is developed throughout Isaiah, but especially in 61:1–63:6 (34:8; 35:9 and notes).

had come. The future is already seen through faith.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 63:7
rsbNotes.text: 63:7 I will recount. Isaiah will proclaim aloud (Ps. 51:13–15; 89:1; 145:7) the Lord’s mighty acts of the past, described as His “steadfast love.”

rsbNotes.title: Isa 63:8
rsbNotes.text: 63:8 children who will not deal falsely. These are faithful children of God (Ex. 4:22; Deut. 14:1), unlike the rebellious children described in 1:2–4.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 63:9
rsbNotes.text:
63:9 affliction. Israel’s sufferings in Egypt (Ex. 2:23–25).

angel of his presence. See Ex. 14:19; 23:20–23.

carried. Cf. Ex. 19:4; Deut. 1:31; 32:10–12.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 63:10
rsbNotes.text: 63:10 grieved his Holy Spirit. Rebellion against God’s word brought the patience of God’s Spirit to an end (cf. Ps. 106:33; Acts 7:51; Eph. 4:30). Divine patience is long suffering, but it will not restrain God’s judgment forever.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 63:11
rsbNotes.text:
63:11 days of old. That is, the period of the Exodus and wilderness wanderings.

shepherds of his flock. Moses was this shepherd. Jesus is our shepherd (Heb. 3:1–6; 13:20).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 63:16
rsbNotes.text:
63:16 our Father. God has always been the Father of His people (64:8; Ex. 4:22, 23; Jer. 3:4, 19); they are His children by adoption (Deut. 32:6; Rom. 8:15).

Abraham. See 51:2.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 63:17
rsbNotes.text: 63:17 make us wander. God makes those who reject Him stray (Rom. 1:20–25; 2 Thess. 2:10–12), and may confirm them in their sin (6:10; Ex. 4:21; Ps. 95:8).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 63:18
rsbNotes.text: 63:18 our adversaries. The Babylonians (Ps. 74:4–8).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 63:19
rsbNotes.text: 63:19 called by your name. To signify ownership (Deut. 28:10; Jer. 14:9).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 64:1
rsbNotes.text: 64:1 Oh that you would . . . come down. With eloquence Isaiah pleads with God to make His presence unmistakably clear, especially in the fires of judgment (4:4, 5 and notes; Ex. 19:18; Heb. 12:18).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 64:3
rsbNotes.text: 64:3 awesome things. An allusion to God’s appearance on Mount Sinai after the Exodus (Ex. 19:16–18; Deut. 10:21; Ps. 66:3–6; 106:22; see Ezek. 32:6–8 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 64:6
rsbNotes.text:
64:6 unclean. Unfit to be in God’s presence (Lev. 13:45, 46; Hag. 2:13, 14).

polluted garment. Garments stained by menstruation (Lev. 15:19; Ezek. 36:17; cf. Phil. 4:7, 8). No one is sinless in God’s sight (6:5; Job 15:14–16).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 64:8
rsbNotes.text:
64:8 our Father. See note 63:16.

clay . . . work of your hand. See notes 22:11; 27:11; cf. Rom. 9:20, 21.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 64:9
rsbNotes.text: 64:9 Compare the promises of 43:25; 54:7, 8.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 64:10
rsbNotes.text: 64:10 holy cities. The cities of Judah.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 64:11
rsbNotes.text: 64:11 our fathers. The speakers are at least a generation removed from the fall of the temple in 586 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:1
rsbNotes.text:
65:1 Here am I. This is repeated for emphasis. God’s presence is salvation.

a nation that was not called by my name. That is, Gentiles (42:1; 49:6). Paul quotes this prophecy in Rom. 10:20. God’s salvation does not conform to human expectations; it originates in His free decision. See Rom. 9:11, 12, 25, 26; 10:30, 31; 11:6, 17 on this important principle.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:2
rsbNotes.text: 65:2 spread out my hands. Unlike the people whose “hands are full of blood” (1:15), the Lord reached out with love.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:3
rsbNotes.text:
65:3 to my face. They did not hide their offensive, idolatrous acts.

sacrificing in gardens. These sacrifices were associated with fertility religions (1:29 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:4
rsbNotes.text:
65:4 sit in tombs. They go there to consult the spirits of the dead (8:19; 29:4).

pig’s flesh. Eating pork was prohibited (66:3, 17; Lev. 11:7, 8; Deut. 14:8).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:5
rsbNotes.text: 65:5 smoke . . . fire. They are a constant annoyance to God.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:6
rsbNotes.text: 65:6 repay. The principle of retribution applies in God’s judgment (Obad. 15; Gal. 6:7; 1 Pet. 1:17; Rev. 20:12, 13; 22:12).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:8
rsbNotes.text: 65:8 new wine. The new wine in the cluster is the remnant for whose sake the whole is preserved (Matt. 13:29). The remnant is among both Israel (1:9 note) and the nations (56:6; cf. Gen. 18:22–33).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:9
rsbNotes.text: 65:9 my chosen shall possess it. The kingdom will be theirs (14:1 note; 57:13; cf. Obad. 19–21).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:10
rsbNotes.text:
65:10 Sharon. This fertile plain south of Mt. Carmel, on the Mediterranean coast. It is a picture of how the Lord will transform creation (33:9; 35:1, 2 and notes).

Valley of Achor. South of Jericho (Josh. 7:24; Hos. 2:15).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:11
rsbNotes.text: 65:11 Fortune . . . Destiny. Syrian gods.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:15
rsbNotes.text:
65:15 for a curse. This is an even worse fate than being forgotten.

another name. See note 62:2.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:16
rsbNotes.text: 65:16 God of truth. the Hebrew word translated “truth” is “amen”; see 2 Cor. 1:20; Rev. 3:14; also John 14:6; 1 John 5:20.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:17
rsbNotes.text:
65:17 new heavens and a new earth. This prophecy awaits the Second Coming of Christ (2 Pet. 3:13; Rev. 21:1). In the meantime through faith the saints experience in part the blessing of the age to come (42:9; 43:19 and notes). See “Heaven” at Rev. 21:1.

the former. The adversities and disgrace brought on by sin (41:22 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:18
rsbNotes.text: 65:18 create Jerusalem. It will be altogether new with no remembrance of the old (Rev. 21:1, 2).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:20
rsbNotes.text: 65:20 infant . . . old man. Premature death of infants or persons in mid-career can provoke the thought that life is meaningless. Such early death, as also the transfer of one person’s reward to another person who did not earn it (v. 22), is part of God’s judgment on sin. God promises to remove this curse from His people (Amos 5:11 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 65:25
rsbNotes.text: 65:25 dust shall be the serpent’s food. This alludes to Gen. 3:14. The curse on Satan is carried out.
